definitions.definition: To act upon with a rake , or as if with a rake.
examples: She is raking the gravel path to keep it even.
We raked all the leaves into a pile.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive , also figurative ) Often followed by in : to gather ( things which are apart ) together, especially quickly .
examples: The casino is just raking in the cash; it’s like a licence to print money.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) Often followed by an adverb or preposition such as away , off , out , etc.: to drag or pull in a certain direction .
( ambitransitive , figurative ) To claw at; to scrape , to scratch ; followed by away : to erase , to obliterate .
examples: The cat’s sharp claws raked the side of my face.

subdefinitions.definition: ( ambitransitive , figurative ) Followed by up : to bring up or uncover (something), as embarrassing information , past misdeeds , etc.
( ambitransitive , figurative ) To search through ( thoroughly ).

( ambitransitive , also figurative ) To move (a beam of light , a glance with the eyes , etc.) across (something) with a long side-to-side motion ; specifically ( often military ) to use a weapon to fire at (something) with a side-to-side motion; to spray with gunfire . ( military , nautical ) To fire upon an enemy vessel from a position in line with its bow or stern , causing one's fire to travel through the length of the enemy vessel for maximum damage .
examples: The enemy machine guns raked the roadway.

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive , chiefly Ireland , Northern England , Scotland , also figurative ) To cover (something) by or as if by raking things over it.
To pick (a lock) with a rake.

main_definition: To act upon with a rake , or as if with a rake.

definitions.definition: Alternative spelling of raik (“ ( intransitive , Midlands , Northern England , Scotland ) to walk ; to roam , to wander ; of animals (especially sheep ): to graze ; ( transitive , chiefly Scotland ) to roam or wander through (somewhere)”)

main_definition: Alternative spelling of raik (“ ( intransitive , Midlands , Northern England , Scotland ) to walk ; to roam , to wander ; of animals (especially sheep ): to graze ; ( transitive , chiefly Scotland ) to roam or wander through (somewhere)”)

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , chiefly Midlands , Northern England , Scotland ) To move swiftly ; to proceed rapidly .
( intransitive , falconry ) Of a bird of prey : to fly after a quarry ; also, to fly away from the falconer , to go wide of the quarry being pursued .

main_definition: ( intransitive , chiefly Midlands , Northern England , Scotland ) To move swiftly ; to proceed rapidly .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive , falconry ) Of a bird of prey : to fly after a quarry ; also, to fly away from the falconer , to go wide of the quarry being pursued .

definitions.definition: ( ambitransitive ) To incline (something) from a perpendicular direction .

subdefinitions.definition: ( transitive ) To provide (the bow or stern of a watercraft) with a rake ( “ a slant that causes it to extend beyond the keel ” ) .
( intransitive , rare ) Of a watercraft: to have a rake at its bow or stern.

main_definition: ( ambitransitive ) To incline (something) from a perpendicular direction .

definitions.definition: To behave as a rake ; to lead a hedonistic and immoral life .

main_definition: ( intransitive , dated , rare ) To behave as a rake ; to lead a hedonistic and immoral life .
